messageBody:
Currently, no, because the output in the failed assertion gives us
the line number, so I just want the text to indicate what we're
expecting. If I get three identical messages, they will fail on
different line numbers.

If I didn't have the line numbers, I might make an AssertTestSetup
method....hmmm...although now that you mention that, I just might do
that on Monday morning when I get to work anyway :)

-Eric

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> ericheikkila wrote:
> > Hmmm....sounds like you're trying to over-engineer the problem.
> >
> > Why not have a unit test for the database connection. If that
> > fails, then all your database dependant tests fail, you know that
> > the connection could not be established due to the DB connection
> > test. The fact that the other tests fail as a side effect is
> > somewhat irrelevant.
> >
> > The other suggestion I saw about doing asserts in setup could be
> > used, too. Or, something I currently do (an idea blatantly
stolen
> > from my co-workers), if testing some pre-existing condition is to
> > simply notate:
> >
> > assertEquals("Test setup: This should be zero initially", 0,
> > someClass.Value());
> >
> > Then if a 'test setup' assert is thrown, you know that there was
> > something wrong before you even made it to the asserts you were
> > really testing. Very useful, simple, and doesn't require some
grand
> > mechanism.
>
> When you write three of those, you have duplication in the failure
> message. Wouldn't you like to refactor that?
